) Purpose: IRM

, Employee Plans Examination of Returns, Bankruptcy Procedures, provides guidance for Employee Plans (EP) agents to use to and properly identify and work situations where the plan sponsor, or other appli- cable entity, is in bankruptcy, or a distinct possibility exists that they will ﬁle bankruptcy protection in the near future. (
) Audience: This IRM provides procedures for agents, their group managers and support staff in EP Exam. (
) Program Owner: Director, EP Examinations. (

) To protect the Government and plan participants from loss when a plan sponsor or other entity is in bankruptcy, or when there are signiﬁcant difficulties that could result in the ﬁling of bankruptcy, EP agents, their managers and support staff must work with Employee Retirement Income Security Act of
(ERISA) Titles I and IV, and the bankruptcy laws. (
) Policy Statement

provides the primary objective of the Employee Plans examination program is regulatory, with emphasis on continued qualiﬁcation employee beneﬁt plans. The purpose of selecting and examining returns is to promote the highest degree of voluntary compliance with the tax laws governing plan qualiﬁcation. Such purpose is also to determine the extent of compliance and the causes of noncompliance with the tax laws by qualiﬁed plans. Plans will also be examined to determine whether such plans meet applicable qualiﬁcation requirements in operation. (
) In accordance with Policy Statement
, EP agents and managers: (

The purpose of selecting and examining returns is to promote the highest degree of voluntary compliance with the tax laws governing plan qualiﬁcation. Such purpose is also to determine the extent of compliance and the causes of noncompliance with the tax laws by qualiﬁed plans. In accordance with Policy Statement 4-117, EP agents and managers:
Employee Plans Examination of Returns

a. Have been given broad authority to consider and weigh conﬂicting mation, data, and opinions. b. Will use professional judgement in accordance with examination standards to make ﬁndings of fact and apply the Service’s position on issues of law to determine the correct tax liability. c. Will exercise this authority to obtain the greatest number of agreements to tax determinations without sacriﬁcing the quality or integrity of those determinations. Also, this authority will be used to dispose of tax differ- ences at the lowest level. (
) All examinations will be done in accordance with Policy Statement
, Fairness and Integrity in Enforcement Selection. (

Examining the qualiﬁed plan of a plan sponsor who is insolvent or has ﬁled federal bankruptcy protection imposes unique challenges on EP agents. This IRM discusses some of the issues and examination procedures that be applicable when the sponsor of a qualiﬁed plan has ﬁled, or appears to poised to ﬁle, for federal bankruptcy protection. Identifying and collecting tax and other liabilities from a plan sponsor that ﬁled for bankruptcy requires an understanding of tax, ERISA Titles I and IV, and bankruptcy laws. Coordination between different divisions and functions within the IRS is required. As a result, the agent must use special examination procedures when a sponsor is bankrupt. Automatic Stay: When a debtor ﬁles a petition for bankruptcy protection the bankruptcy court, it results in an Automatic Stay of any creditor from pursuing activity to collect from the debtor. For example, the Automatic Stay generally prevents a creditor from demanding payment, initiating or a lawsuit, including a proceeding before the U.S. Tax Court, or perfecting a lien.
Examining the qualiﬁed plan of a plan sponsor who is insolvent or has ﬁled for federal bankruptcy protection imposes unique challenges on EP agents.
Employee Plans Examination of (
) Bankruptcy Estate: When a debtor begins bankruptcy action, the debtor’s property generally becomes the property of a new taxable entity, the Bank- ruptcy Estate. (

) Bankruptcy Trustee: The Bankruptcy Trustee or the debtor-in-possession manages the Bankruptcy Estate under the supervision of the bankruptcy and is generally responsible for preparing and ﬁling the Bankruptcy Estate’s tax returns. (

) Bar Date: The Bar Date is the date ﬁxed by the court or by statute and is date by which a creditor must ﬁle a Proof of Claim. If the IRS asserts tax ties after the Bar Date in a federal bankruptcy case, they are deemed to be untimely, and any tax assessments must be abated. The amount of the tax liability asserted in a Proof of Claim may be adjusted or modiﬁed, even after the Bar Date, provided the Proof of Claim has been timely ﬁled with the ruptcy court. The Bar Date is generally the later of - a.
days after the petition date, or b.
days after the ﬁrst meeting of the creditors. (
) Chapter
Proceedings: A proceeding ﬁled under Chapter
of the Code is where the debtor’s available assets are liquidated with the proceeds distributed to creditors. a. In a Chapter

case, the Bankruptcy Trustee collects the debtor’s nonexempt property and converts the property to cash. b. The trustee then distributes the cash to the creditors. c. The ultimate goal of the debtor is to receive a discharge from pre- bankruptcy debts. (
) Chapter
Proceedings: In a Chapter

case, the debtor develops a nization plan to pay its pre-bankruptcy creditors over time. a. The creditors must vote for the debtor’s reorganization plan. b. If the debtor’s plan is not passed, the creditors will propose their own plan. c. If neither the debtor nor the creditors achieve the necessary votes to pass a plan, the debtor liquidates. d. A Chapter
case may be ﬁled by an individual, sole proprietor, tion, partnership, or a Limited Liability Company (LLC). (
) Chapter
Proceedings: In a Chapter
case, like a Chapter

, the indi- vidual debtor develops a payment plan to pay its pre-bankruptcy creditors time. a. The debtor’s payment plan is largely based on their monthly income. b. A reorganization plan must be approved by the court and may be approved for up to
months. (
) Chapter
Proceedings: A Chapter
case provides U.S. creditors with a coordinated forum for foreign bankruptcy proceedings. (
) Governmental Unit: The term Governmental Unit is deﬁned in Bankruptcy Code section
), and includes the United States government. (
) Proof of Claim: A Proof of Claim is an official bankruptcy form a creditor with the bankruptcy court stating the amount a debtor owes to him or her.
Employee Plans Examination of Returns
Chapter 11 Proceedings: In a Chapter 11 case, the debtor develops a nization plan to pay its pre-bankruptcy creditors over time.
Governmental Unit: The term Governmental Unit is deﬁned in Bankruptcy Code section 101(27), and includes the United States government.
Proof of Claim: A Proof of Claim is an official bankruptcy form a creditor ﬁles with the bankruptcy court stating the amount a debtor owes to him or her.

Note: In a bankruptcy case, the debtor is required to identify creditors. The creditors are then permitted to ﬁle a Proof of Claim form substantiating debt. A Proof of Claim form will contain details regarding the debt and porting evidence, such as relevant documentation. (

) Reportable Event: Both publicly traded and privately held companies must notify the PBGC of Reportable Events. The Reportable Events that arise often include: • Bankruptcy • A change in contributing sponsor or controlled group • The failure to make required minimum payments • Inability to pay beneﬁts when due • Active participant reductions • Loan default • Liquidation of the contributing sponsor or a controlled group (
) While an EP agent does not necessarily participate in bankruptcy court dures, it’s very helpful for you (the agent) to understand these procedures cases where the plan sponsor is bankrupt. (
) Every debtor is required to attend the ﬁrst meeting of creditors (often
meeting). a. The meeting is conducted by a court appointed trustee. b. Creditors and the trustee question the debtors under oath about affairs, debts and assets. (
) The assets of a plan qualiﬁed under IRC
(a) are generally excluded the Bankruptcy Estate, and as such, the plan assets are not subject to the claims of the debtor’s creditors. (
) The Bankruptcy Estate also speciﬁcally excludes any amount the employer withheld from employee wages or received from employees for payment contributions to: • Plans under IRC
(a) • Plans under IRC
, including SEP IRAs, SIMPLE IRAs, or IRAs • Governmental plans (within the meaning of IRC
(d)) • Deferred compensation plans under IRC
• IRC
(b) plans (

) Under the Bankruptcy Code, certain claims are given priority over others certain claims are paid before others). a. In a situation where the Bankruptcy Estate is limited, and insufficient satisfy all of the outstanding liabilities, having a priority claim is very important. b. In the case of compensation, beneﬁts and pension contribution tions, whether a claim is entitled to a priority may depend on if the arose pre-petition or post-petition. (
) Claims in bankruptcy court are generally divided into pre-petition and post- petition. Internal Revenue Manual

(12-03-2018) General Bankruptcy Principles

a. In a situation where the Bankruptcy Estate is limited, and insufficient to satisfy all of the outstanding liabilities, having a priority claim is very important. b. In the case of compensation, beneﬁts and pension contribution obliga
tions, whether a claim is entitled to a priority may depend on if the liability arose pre

Claims in bankruptcy court are generally divided into pre-petition and post-
Employee Plans Examination of a. Pre-petition means the claim arose before ﬁling the bankruptcy b. Post-petition means the claim arose after the bankruptcy petition was ﬁled. (

) Creditors’ claims generally fall into one or more of the following: • Secured. A secured claim has a lien, security interest, or other brance which has been properly perfected as required by law with respect to property owned by the debtor. A secured claim entitles a creditor to a higher priority of payment from the debtor’s assets. • Unsecured priority. An unsecured priority claim has priority over unsecured claims. Section
of the Bankruptcy Code lists of priority claims in order of priority. Unsecured priority creditors have their own hierarchy of payment under section
of the Bankruptcy Code. If a creditor falls within one of the numbered paragraphs of section

of the Bankruptcy Code, that paragraph will indicate the priority of payment – ﬁrst, second, third, fourth, etc. • Unsecured. An unsecured claim is not entitled to either secured or priority status. An unsecured creditor is generally paid after a creditor. (

) Administrative claims are the actual, necessary expenses that arise from ordinary business operations of the Bankruptcy Estate. a. The administrative claims are unsecured, but are given priority status ordinary and necessary business expenses of the Bankruptcy Estate. b. Tax liabilities incurred by the Bankruptcy Estate constitute claims. (
) The agent should pay special attention to the actions of the employer when examining the plan. Issues (

) As an employer’s ﬁnancial situation worsens the chance that it will take Bankruptcy pension-related actions to reduce its insolvency increase. Those actions include: • Eliminating or suspending employer proﬁt sharing and/or matching tributions • Freezing beneﬁt accruals under deﬁned beneﬁt plans • Terminating pension plans • Seeking ﬁnancing through an ESOP • Reducing employee pay or work hours, or terminating employees • File for federal bankruptcy protection • Entering into a state law assignment for the beneﬁt of creditors (

) Additionally, due to the employer’s actions to reduce its insolvency, will also commonly take pension-related actions, including: • Taking more plan loans, hardship or other in-service distributions deﬁned contribution plans • Requesting distributions based on retirement, early retirement or nation of employment under deﬁned beneﬁt or deﬁned contribution plans (
) The bankruptcy of the plan sponsor may (or may not) affect the tax the trust, participants and beneﬁciaries, disqualiﬁed persons and ﬁduciaries. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

The bankruptcy of the plan sponsor may (or may not) affect the tax liabilities of the trust, participants and beneﬁciaries, disqualiﬁed persons and ﬁduciaries.

The plan’s trust, its participants and beneﬁciaries, and disqualiﬁed persons other than the employer, are separate entities from the plan sponsor. Therefore, the agent may continue to pursue the trust’s and participant’s income tax liabilities or the disqualiﬁed person’s excise tax liabilities, even if the plan sponsor is in bankruptcy. For example:

) When a bankruptcy involves a member of a controlled group or affiliated service group, the agent should determine which members ﬁled for and who has the obligation to pay beneﬁts. a. In some instances the legal entity that employs certain workers, and entity that is obligated to provide beneﬁts, are not the same. b. For example, the common law employees of a subsidiary may receive beneﬁts from that entity’s parent. c. All the related entities may not have ﬁled for bankruptcy protection. d. Therefore, it is essential to identify all members of the bankrupt entity’s controlled group (or affiliated service group), and determine if any tax other liabilities apply to those members. ) A employer’s attempt to contribute debentures to a plan in lieu of cash contri- butions, or to provide less beneﬁts than participants are entitled to, would create a minimum funding issue in a pension plan and may constitute a dis- qualifying defect with respect to the plan. (
) It may be that the plan sponsor is bankrupt, but the company’s deﬁned pension plan is overfunded. In this case, the employer may seek to access surplus assets without paying the full IRC

excise tax on reversions. The agent should determine if the plan sponsor or trustee has taken any of these actions: a. Terminated the plan and distributed or transferred excess assets to the plan sponsor. b. Completed a transaction intended to directly or indirectly sell the assets to another entity. c. Merged an overfunded plan with another entity’s plan or with another plan of the plan sponsor. d. Transferred assets of an overfunded plan into the plan of another entity or into another plan of the plan sponsor.

) If an employer sponsors a plan that has excess assets, the sponsor may reclaim those extra assets if the plan has satisﬁed all the employees’ earned beneﬁt obligations. Before the plan sponsor can recover the excess assets, must fully vest participants and purchase annuity contracts to pay all earned beneﬁts. (
) When the plan sponsor terminates the plan, and receives a reversion, the sponsor incurs taxes. These taxes include: • Corporate income tax on the amount of the reversion • Nondeductible

) An employer with insolvency issues will tend to shrink or curtail operations time, which may result in a partial plan termination. a. The Treasury regulations provide that whether a partial termination occurs is based on the relevant facts and circumstances. b. Under IRC

), upon a partial termination, the rights of all employees accrued to the date of the partial termination, to the extent funded on that date, or the amounts credited to their accounts, must become fully vested. (

) A contributing employer must notify the plan administrator of a deﬁned pension plan of a bankruptcy ﬁling. a. The plan administrator must then notify participants and beneﬁciaries the bankruptcy ﬁling and the limitations of the PBGC’s guarantee in event of a plan termination. b. The DOL may impose a penalty of $
per day for each individual is not given this notice. c. The agent should make sure proper notiﬁcation has been made. (
) IRC
)(A) provides that an employer engaged in a Chapter

bank- ruptcy proceeding may not, subject to certain exceptions (discussed below), adopt an amendment to a qualiﬁed deﬁned beneﬁt pension plan that is effective prior to the employer’s plan of reorganization, if the amendment increases plan liabilities by reason of any: • Increasing beneﬁts • Changing the accrual of beneﬁts • Changing the rate at which beneﬁts become nonforfeitable under the plan (

) Other potential issues to look for when examining plans of bankrupt include: a. Employers ﬁling bankruptcy are also more likely to improperly pull out of the plan and fail to pay deferrals or contributions to the trust (if at all). b. Employers ﬁling bankruptcy may attempt to identify assets as exempt when the funds actually belong to the debtor and should be available the creditors. This leads to improper commingling of funds within the trust. c. In an attempt to satisfy creditors, the trust may improperly attempt to repay loans on behalf of the plan sponsor or make loans to the plan sponsor or other disqualiﬁed person. This improper use of plan would violate IRC

) In general, employers who sponsor single employer deﬁned beneﬁt plans required to contribute the present value of all beneﬁts earned under a plan. a. Each year, the sponsor must re-determine the present value of all beneﬁts earned under the plan as of the end of the previous tax year. b. To the extent the future value of the current plan assets falls short of total earned beneﬁts, the sponsor must make an actuarially adjusted tribution equal to the present value of this deﬁciency. (
) IRC
) requires that a single employer deﬁned beneﬁt plan satisfy requirements of IRC
in order to constitute a qualiﬁed plan. (
) IRC
imposes a number of restrictions on plan amendments, beneﬁts, forms of beneﬁt payment of plans that are not sufficiently funded to satisfy beneﬁt liabilities. (
) IRC

provides that certain qualiﬁed plans must satisfy a minimum obligation. A plan is treated as meeting this minimum funding obligation if: a. In the case of a deﬁned beneﬁt plan that is not a multiemployer plan, employer makes contributions required under IRC

b. In the case of a money purchase plan that is not a multiemployer the employer makes contributions as required under the terms of the plan. c. In the case of a multiemployer plan, the employers make sufficient butions so that the plan does not have an accumulated funding under IRC
) Generally, in a single employer plan, the plan sponsor is responsible for making the required contributions under a plan.
The plan would have a funding target attainment percentage of

% or more after the amendment takes effect; or The IRS determines that the amendment is reasonable and increases the liabilities of the plan by not more than a de minimis amount; or The amendment only repeals an extraordinary amendment described in IRC
); or The amendment is required to maintain the plan’s tax-qualiﬁed status.

Employers ﬁling bankruptcy are also more likely to improperly pull money out of the plan and fail to pay deferrals or contributions to the trust timely (if at all). Employers ﬁling bankruptcy may attempt to identify assets as exempt when the funds actually belong to the debtor and should be available for the creditors. This leads to improper commingling of funds within the trust. In an attempt to satisfy creditors, the trust may improperly attempt to repay loans on behalf of the plan sponsor or make loans to the plan sponsor or other disqualiﬁed person. This improper use of plan assets would violate IRC

In general, employers who sponsor single employer deﬁned beneﬁt plans required to contribute the present value of all beneﬁts earned under a plan. a. Each year, the sponsor must re-determine the present value of all beneﬁts earned under the plan as of the end of the previous tax year. b. To the extent the future value of the current plan assets falls short of total earned beneﬁts, the sponsor must make an actuarially adjusted tribution equal to the present value of this deﬁciency. provides that certain qualiﬁed plans must satisfy a minimum obligation. A plan is treated as meeting this minimum funding obligation if: a. In the case of a deﬁned beneﬁt plan that is not a multiemployer plan, employer makes contributions required under IRC

b. In the case of a money purchase plan that is not a multiemployer the employer makes contributions as required under the terms of the plan. c. In the case of a multiemployer plan, the employers make sufficient butions so that the plan does not have an accumulated funding under IRC

In general, employers who sponsor single employer deﬁned beneﬁt plans are required to contribute the present value of all beneﬁts earned under a plan.
a. Each year, the sponsor must re

determine the present value of all beneﬁts earned under the plan as of the end of the previous tax year. b. To the extent the future value of the current plan assets falls short of the total earned beneﬁts, the sponsor must make an actuarially adjusted con
tribution equal to the present value of this deﬁciency.

Each year, the sponsor must re-determine the present value of all beneﬁts earned under the plan as of the end of the previous tax year. To the extent the future value of the current plan assets falls short of the total earned beneﬁts, the sponsor must make an actuarially adjusted tribution equal to the present value of this deﬁciency.
IRC 401(a)(29) requires that a single employer deﬁned beneﬁt plan satisfy the requirements of IRC 436 in order to constitute a qualiﬁed plan.
IRC 412 provides that certain qualiﬁed plans must satisfy a minimum funding obligation. A plan is treated as meeting this minimum funding obligation if:
a. In the case of a deﬁned beneﬁt plan that is not a multiemployer plan, the employer makes contributions required under IRC

b. In the case of a money purchase plan that is not a multiemployer plan, the employer makes contributions as required under the terms of the plan. c. In the case of a multiemployer plan, the employers make sufficient butions so that the plan does not have an accumulated funding under IRC
Generally, in a single employer plan, the plan sponsor is responsible for making the required contributions under a plan.

Plans not covered by the PBGC, among others, include:

• Individual account plans • Governmental plans • Plans established and maintained outside of the U.S. primarily for the beneﬁt of individuals substantially all of whom are nonresident aliens • Plans established and maintained exclusively for substantial owners • A plan established and maintained by a professional service employer that has never had more than
active participants in the plan (
) When an underfunded deﬁned beneﬁt plan covered by PBGC is terminated, the PBGC may step in and pay beneﬁts. (
) If a plan sponsor wants to terminate its deﬁned beneﬁt pension plan, but cannot fund all earned beneﬁts, it may voluntarily ﬁle for a distress with the PBGC. (
) A plan sponsor seeking a distress termination must send a notice of intent to terminate, and ﬁle required forms with PBGC similar to those in a standard mination as required by ERISA section

) The PBGC may start proceedings for an involuntary deﬁned beneﬁt pension plan termination if they determine that the PBGC may be subject to a long term loss with respect to the plan if the plan is not terminated. (

) During any plan examination, it is important to determine as soon as whether the plan sponsor is in bankruptcy or may soon ﬁle for bankruptcy. Procedures agent may determine that the sponsor has ﬁled for bankruptcy through the following means: a. On IDRS, research TXMODA or BMFOLT and look for TC
with a closing code:

b. On IDRS, research AMDISA and look for an “X” or “U” freeze code depending on when the bankruptcy was ﬁled. You may also just see word “bankruptcy” on the AMDISA print. c. Obtain a bankruptcy report through Accurint. d. During the initial examination interview, ask the plan sponsor if they any bankruptcy ﬁlings, or if they are planning to ﬁle for bankruptcy. e. Notiﬁcation from EP Classiﬁcation. Note: EP Classiﬁcation may also notify the agent of a bankruptcy ﬁling. (

) If, upon examination of the plan, the agent discovers that the plan sponsor ﬁled for federal bankruptcy protection, the following procedures should be taken: a. Inform your manager that you have a taxpayer that is in bankruptcy. b. Contact SB/SE Insolvency (Insolvency). Go to the Insolvency web site determine who the Insolvency contact is for your state. c. Determine the Bar Date. Note: The Insolvency specialist will assist in the determination of the Bar Date. (
) Consider all the facts and circumstances surrounding the case. If the agent and group manager decide to survey the case, they must notify Insolvency this decision. (

If, upon examination of the plan, the agent discovers that the plan sponsor has ﬁled for federal bankruptcy protection, the following procedures should be

a. Inform your manager that you have a taxpayer that is in bankruptcy. b. Contact SB/SE Insolvency (Insolvency). Go to the Insolvency web site to determine who the Insolvency contact is for your state. c. Determine the Bar Date.
Consider all the facts and circumstances surrounding the case. If the agent and group manager decide to survey the case, they must notify Insolvency of
Employee Plans Examination of (
) If the case meets the criteria for signiﬁcant bankruptcy case processing (refer to IRM
, Signiﬁcant Bankruptcy Case Issues, for criteria) contact Area Counsel. (
) If the plan is a deﬁned beneﬁt plan covered by the PBGC, make a referral to the PBGC. Refer to IRM
, EP Group Procedures – Making Referrals Pension Beneﬁt Guaranty Corporation (PBGC). (

) If you need to secure a statute of limitations extension for a plan for which plan sponsor has ﬁled for bankruptcy and you have questions regarding who the trustee is, contact Area Counsel to ensure that you have properly completed Form
-H and Form
and they are signed by the appropriate person. (
) It is important to check the applicable Bar Date as soon as you determine the taxpayer has ﬁled for bankruptcy. (

) If you determine the plan sponsor is insolvent, but the Bar Date has not passed: a. Determine if any excise tax or income tax is due. b. Notify Insolvency of any potential assessment so that they can timely a Proof of Claim with the bankruptcy court. c. If you cannot make a ﬁnal determination of tax, interest and penalties, estimate them to the best of your ability, based on all the facts. d. Upon completing your examination, notify Insolvency of the correct ﬁnal determination so they can ﬁle an amended claim. e. Make sure that you add issues that may have possible tax liabilities as focused issues for your case (e.g., late deferrals for
(k) plans, minimum funding for pension plans, nondeductible contributions and hibited transactions for all plans). (

) Refer the case to the DOL if: a. The plan is a deﬁned beneﬁt or money purchase pension plan that has not been funded properly. Note: DOL has the ability to ﬁle a lawsuit on behalf of the participants to recover this money. b. There have been any misuses of trust assets, so that the DOL may ﬁle lawsuit on behalf of the plan to recover any lost assets. Note: Also contact the EP Fraud Subject Matter Expert (EP Fraud SME) or the TEGE Fraud Specialist if plan assets have been misused. See IRM EP Examinations Fraud Procedures. Find contact information for the EP Fraud SME and the TEGE Fraud Specialist on the TEGE Home Page at Fraud Contacts link. (
) After you have completed the examination of tax-related issues and an RAR or other justiﬁcation for the tax due to the Insolvency specialist, continue the examination as a normal examination. (
) Any qualiﬁcation issues discovered should be corrected using the Employee Plans Compliance Resolution System (EPCRS), or through a Delegation
closing agreement. See IRM
, Closing Agreements. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

Procedures
) Carefully consider whether or not there has been, or is, any misuse of assets or exclusive beneﬁt rule violations under IRC

). a. If you suspect misappropriation or misuse of trust assets, contact the Fraud SME to assess the indications of potential fraud. b. If the plan sponsor has been misusing the trust assets, contact Insol- vency and/or Counsel to determine if assets can be recovered from plan sponsor. c. Consider pursuing prohibited transactions against other disqualiﬁed persons who are not in bankruptcy (e.g., the ﬁduciary). d. Also, if there have been any large or unusual contributions to the discuss it with the Insolvency agent and/or Counsel. (
) If the plan sponsor is unwilling or unable to correct plan qualiﬁcation close the case unagreed to EP Mandatory Review in accordance with IRM
, Unagreed Form

) If a plan sponsor successfully undergoes a bankruptcy reorganization, it emerge from bankruptcy protection according to its reorganization plan. Note: If the plan sponsor has emerged from bankruptcy, you should see a TC posting on the BMFOL. This TC
is posted to reverse the TC
posts when the taxpayer ﬁles for bankruptcy protection. (
) EP Classiﬁcation is notiﬁed by Insolvency of all employers that maintain a pension plan that have ﬁled for bankruptcy. See IRM
, The Role of solvency, for a description of Insolvency Responsibilities. (
) When EP Classiﬁcation is notiﬁed, the Bar Date is often near expiration provides little or no time to do an examination and submit a claim before expiration of the Bar Date. (
) EP Classiﬁcation may assign bankruptcy referrals for pension plan issues a Bar Date has passed or about to pass. (
) The EP agent should make every effort to contact Insolvency before the ration of the Bar Date so that Insolvency can timely ﬁle a Proof of Claim. (
) If the Bar Date has expired and the EP agent determines excise tax is notify your Insolvency contact to determine if a Proof of Claim can still be Refer to IRM
), Bankruptcy Procedures, on how to determine Insolvency contact. (
) Issues concerning the pension plan should be resolved where excise tax involved. (
) Pension plan assets should not be used to resolve bankruptcy issues. (
) EP Classiﬁcation may hold a bankruptcy referral for the subsequent year to determine if any new violations may have occurred. (
) Internal Revenue Manual
Carefully consider whether or not there has been, or is, any misuse of trust assets or exclusive beneﬁt rule violations under IRC 401(a)(2).
If a plan sponsor successfully undergoes a bankruptcy reorganization, it will emerge from bankruptcy protection according to its reorganization plan.
EP Classiﬁcation may hold a bankruptcy referral for the subsequent year to determine if any new violations may have occurred.
